metadata.title: Quick and Dirty Data Visualization Toolbox | by Vincent Tatan | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Quick and Dirty Data Visualization Toolbox
metadata.description: Data visualization is paramount to understand the beauty of data analytics. Through data visualization, our stakeholders understand the impacts of our analysis. It helps them focus and make informed…

all_paragraphs: Most of us need to listen to the music to understand how beautiful it is. But often that’s how we present statistics: we just show the notes, we don’t play the music. — Hans Rosling

Data visualization is paramount to understand the beauty of data analytics. Through data visualization, our stakeholders understand the impacts of our analysis. It helps them focus and make informed decisions.
However, despite its importance, I always received questions from aspiring data scientists on how they can start exploring data analytics.
Since there are common scenarios which are applicable across various datasets types, I would like to focus on demonstrating these code snippets so that you could easily plug and play.

These are the code snippets that are derived from my personal working experience at Google and Visa whenever I conduct a new data exploratory and deep dives — my toolbox for quick and dirty data visualization.

By the end of this article, you should start implementing these codes and visualize your data faster and more efficient. Regardless of how clean your data is, you can directly run these codes and extract insights.
If you’d like to further experiment these tools on Iris Dataset and HR Retention Dataset. Feel free to visit this Colab link and run them.

I always recommend, Matplotlib and Seaborn to get >80% typical data visualization done. If you use Colab, these libraries have been preinstalled for you. If not, run the following on your packet manager.

Pie chart is always useful to show the count class distributions across a feature. This is greatly useful to look into target variable class distribution and conduct sanity check depends on our prior knowledge.

For example, if we analyse the three classes in Iris Dataset, we expect similar counts per class. But in Gmail spam/ham detection, we expect skewed class distributions. The number of spams should be fewer than the number of hams.
You should use this when… there is a categorical target variable.
Distribution plot shows continuous feature distributions to detect outliers, skewness, and kurtosis visually.

It helps you understand not only the current distribution but also the outliers or edge cases (such as negative values). This helps you understand your dataset and design subsequent data cleaning and transformation.
You should use this when… there are n continuous features.
Layered Boxplot is another distribution visualization to visualize different distribution per class and find key patterns quickly.
In the visualization below, just at a quick glance, you know that class ‘setosa’ have very low distribution in sepal_length, petal_length, and petal_width.
This gives you a quick glimpse of what matters and allows you to prioritize efforts on data cleaning and transformation.
You should use this when… there are n continuous features with categorical target feature.
Factorplot visualizes categorical count distribution per class and find key patterns quickly. It is a Seaborn out of box visualization and no customization is necessary.
You should use this when… there is one categorical feature with categorical target feature.
Heatmap visualizes correlations within n continuous feature. Combines with pd.DataFrame.corr(), it visualizes which feature correlates to each other.
The goal of correlation analysis is giving you what features correlates to each other which might impede insights generation and model learning.
In the example below, the last number_project is highly correlated to last_evaluation and average_monthly_hour. This makes sense because the more project you have the more hours you need to work.

If you dump these features into regression learning model (GLM) without handling their correlation properly, the regression will overplay the importance of both features which essentially send the same signal.
You should use this when… there are n continuous features
Seaborn pairplot runs classes distributions in each feature pair. Pairplot is a quick way to visualize distributions among numbers of features.
The underlying caveat is that it could be noisy if you have many features. But you could fix and filter the features with feature selections techniques such as Principal Component Analysis (PCA).
You should use this when… there are n continuous features with target variable

This ensemble further facilitates feature to feature relationship to affect target variable. Based on your hypothesis (from pairplot or your own observations), you could select these features and plot quickly.
In the example below, you could see quickly that there are 3 clusters which determine employees left:
Even without Clustering ML model, scatterplots gives us insights and hypothesis on why employees quit:
You should use this when… there are 2 continuous features and target variable. This should be paired with your hypothesis.

I believe these codes are simple to implement straight away in your first data exploration. This visualization toolbox will give you the head start you need to become more confident in exploring and visualizing your data.
As always, please reach out to me on Linkedin for any of your questions. I would be glad to answer your queries when time permits.

Vincent Tatan is a Data and Technology enthusiast with relevant working experiences from Google LLC, Visa Inc. and Lazada to conduct microservice architectures, business intelligence, and analytics pipeline projects.
Vincent is a native Indonesian with a record of accomplishments in problem-solving with strengths in Full Stack Development, Data Analytics, and Strategic Planning.
He has been actively consulting SMU BI & Analytics Club, guiding aspiring data scientists and engineers, and opening up his expertise for businesses to develop their products.
Lastly, please reach out to Vincent via LinkedIn, Medium or Youtube Channel
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
